Title:
Identification and Characterization of Colletotrichum Species
Associated with Pearl Plum Anthracnose in Guangxi
Keywords:
Pearl plum, Colletotrichum, morphology, phylogeny,
pathogenicity
Abstract:
Pearl plum (Prunus salicina Lindl.) is mainly cultivated
in Tiane County in Guangxi Province, southern China. Anthracnose is a
devastating disease on pearl plum, causing considerable leaf blight.
Diseased leaves and fruits were sampled from 21 orchards in Tiane County
in Guangxi Province. Colletotrichum isolates were obtained in these
orchards, and 23 isolates were selected for sequencing of the internal
transcribed spacer (ITS), Apn2-Mat1-2 intergenic spacer and partial
mating type (Mat1-2) gene (ApMat), a partial sequence of the actin
(ACT), an intron of the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
(GAPDH), calmodulin (CAL), chitin synthase A gene (CHS-1), and the
β-tubulin (TUB2). Based on colony, conidial, and appressorial morphology
and sequences analyses, the Colletotrichum isolates associated with
pearl plum anthracnose were identified as four species: Colletotrichum
fructicola (18 isolates, 79%), C. gloeosporioides (3 isolates, 13%), C.
kahawae (1 isolate, 4%), and C. siamense (1 isolate, 4%). The results of
pathogenicity test showed that all isolates were pathogenic to pearl
plum leaves. No relationship was found between virulence and
Colletotrichum species tested. This is the first report of C.
fructicola, and C. kahawae causing anthracnose on pearl plum in
China.
